text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from
English with Jennifer. Which thing

can we count? Water
or a bottle?

A bottle. Right? One bottle, two bottles.
Which thing can we count? Sand
or a beach?

A beach. One beach, two beaches.
Water and sand

are uncountable. Let's practice
using countable and uncountable nouns.

You can study with my students, Flavia
and Andreia.

It's time to learn some basic grammar
through conversation.

So, very quickly, let's do a review
because you need to remember --

What can we count? What can we not count?
And that's the difference between "many"
and "much." Okay? So, for example, just tell me what do you see?
Many flowers? You see many flowers. Beautiful red flowers. I think they're tulips.

Okay. What do you see?
Many candies. Aha! You could...if you say
"candies." All different kinds of candies. Many candies.
But all together, we could also say

"much" or "a lot." There's a lot of candy.
Candy is one of those words, like a group.

Fruit, candy, pasta. Right? Lots of
food categories are uncountable. That's a
lot of candy. But you could say, "Oh! Many candies."

Because there's different types. Okay?
What do you see in that picture?
Many shoes.
There are many shoes and many boots. Many different kinds.

That's a city. Tell me about it.
What do you see in that city photo?
Much buildings?
Many. Many?

Why? Can we count buildings? Yes.
There are many buildings and also
look at all the lights. Many or much lights?

Much lights? Well, if in this picture
there are many windows...in every window
there's light. So, these are things that we count. Look
at all the lights. Because there are different ones. Right?

Or we can say in this room,
"Oh, there's too much light."

"There's not enough light."
Because we're speaking here in this
place. But in this photo, there's lots of little

lights. Many lights. We talk about the
city lights.

Like the city lights of New York or
Boston...how pretty they are.
Much pasta.

There's so much pasta. There's so much
pasta.
Okay. What do you see?
Many necklace.

Many necklaces. Necklaces. Many necklaces. Uh-huh.
So, "many" and "much" depends on whether it's
countable or uncountable. So, now let's put it
together with "too" and see problems, like there are too
many tourists. In this photo, what's the problem? Why are
people sitting on the train? What's the problem?
Crowded. Too crowded.

It's too crowded. There are
too many people inside, so they're going

on top. Look at that.
Wow. Wow! Too many. Okay. Um.

Do you see that sugar? 
Can you put that sugar in your coffee?
Too much. Too much sugar. That's too much sugar

for one person. Yes. Maybe for a group
it's okay, but that's too much sugar for
one person. Okay. Um, would you enjoy

living in this house? Mm-hmm. You would!
I don't know. Maybe for one day.

A whole year, that would be tough. Could you live 
in that house? Yes. Oh, you could!
Come on! After six months, I think, would you get tired?
Yes. Yeah. Think about it. I think um...
Too big.
It's too big. I think it's too much space. Yeah. Too many rooms.

Okay. You can live here, but you have to
clean it.

Do you want to live here? No.
There's too much to clean. There are

too many rooms to clean.
and there's too much space. Right? So,

yeah, it's nice for a day. What's that?
Vegetables. Would you enjoy that pizza?

Fruit...we can say, um, "a lot of fruit"
"too much fruit." But "vegetables" we can count.

Yeah. Yeah. So, there are many vegetables.
Actually, do you think there are too many?

Or does that look good? Many?
Too  many? Are there too many
vegetables? No, no. Not too much. There are just enough.

Do you think there are enough? Yeah.
Looks good. Yeah. I think, um, it looks
great. There are many vegetables, but there...
for me, there's not enough meat!

Okay. Last question. Okay. This is
a beautiful place. Mm-hmm. Yes. Beautiful.

Okay. Imagine you can go here on your
next vacation.
Lovely. You can take your husbands.
How much time is enough?
Ten days. Ten days is enough. Is that enough for you? Do you want more? Do you want less?
Seven days. Seven days. How about two weeks?

Um, one month. Is that too much? It's too
much.
Too much. Really?

Um, it's beautiful, but for you, is it too
quiet or too far?

Or is it perfect? It's perfect...
for 10 days. For 10 days.
For seven years. Seven years?! Seven days.

Seven days. Um, for a month
maybe that's too much. Why?
Too far. Yeah. I also think they don't have the internet.

So, for seven to ten days, maybe two weeks,
but a whole month...

that's hard. How about you?
Would you like to stay at that beach for
a week? How about a month? Is that too much time?

I think many people would like to stay
there for a long weekend.

We use "many" before countable nouns.
There were so many people.
There were many flowers.

We use "much" before uncountable nouns.
There's so much pasta. That's too much

candy. Note how we use
a singular verb with an uncountable noun.

We can use "a lot of" before countable
and uncountable nouns. I saw a lot of
people. I ate a lot of candy. In fast speech,

"a lot of" sounds like "allotuv." A lot of.
You may also hear "alotta." A lot of.

I saw a lot of people. I ate a lot of
candy.

Remember we can also use "enough" before
countable and
uncountable nouns. Were there enough seats?

There weren't enough seats for everyone.
Was there enough candy? There wasn't
enough candy for all the children.

Look at the words and sort them. Which
words are countable
and which words are uncountable?
Here are the answers.

Now help me choose the right words to
describe some photos.

There are too many books. There isn't
enough space.

There are too many tourists, but they're
all having a lot of fun.

Please don't add too much salt.
Oh no! Do we have enough bowls?

That's a lot of snow. Will he have enough
energy to finish?

How did you do? We'll end here.
